<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A new 1D infinite neutral chain (Ph<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SnO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SeOCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) based on organotin and selenious acid monoethyl ester has been synthesized successfully and characterized by IR, elemental analysis, and X-ray single-crystal diffraction. In the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the Sn atom exists in slightly distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry and the Se center is tri-coordinated with a distorted pyramidal arrangement. It is noted that the synthesis is facile and selenium oxide is directly introduced into synthesis route replacing organoseleninic acid under room temperature.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new 1D infinite neutral chain (Ph3SnO2SeOCH2CH3) n  (1) based on organotin and selenious acid monoethyl ester has been synthesized successfully and characterized by IR, elemental analysis, and X-ray single-crystal diffraction. In the compound 1, the Sn atom exists in slightly distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry and the Se center is tri-coordinated with a distorted pyramidal arrangement. It is noted that the synthesis is facile and selenium oxide is directly introduced into synthesis route replacing organoseleninic acid under room temperature.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Organotin compounds are an important branch of organometallic compounds and are receiving attention for use as reagents or catalysts in organic synthesis . Among organotin compounds, many amazing structures have been discovered which include ladder, drum, cube, cluster and cage . The structural diversity is derived from the nature of different ligands. These ligands such as carboxylic acids, sulfonic acids, phosphinic acids, and phosphonic acids can react with an organotin precursor to produce various organotin compounds containing carboxylate, sulfonate, phosphinate, and phosphonate substituents. It is therefore significant in the structure construction and analysis of diverse organotin precursors and ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Organotin compounds are an important branch of organometallic compounds and are receiving attention for use as reagents or catalysts in organic synthesis . Among organotin compounds, many amazing structures have been discovered which include ladder, drum, cube, cluster and cage . The structural diversity is derived from the nature of different ligands. These ligands such as carboxylic acids, sulfonic acids, phosphinic acids, and phosphonic acids can react with an organotin precursor to produce various organotin compounds containing carboxylate, sulfonate, phosphinate, and phosphonate substituents. It is therefore significant in the structure construction and analysis of diverse organotin precursors and ligands.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Organoseleninic acid, similar to carboxylate/sulfonate/phosphinate group, has two coordination oxygen atoms and one negative charge. Therefore, it was thought worthwhile to research the interaction between organotin species and organoseleninic acid. Chandrasekhar et al. reported the first example of an organotin ester of phenylseleninic acid, <ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SePh moiety functioning as connector between neighboring Sn centers . To date, there have been no further examples reported in the domain of organoseleninate unit acting as bridging ligand. In this report, we synthesized successfully a new 1D infinite neutral chain (Ph<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SnO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SeC<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). It is noted that the synthesis is facile and selenium oxide is directly introduced into synthesis route replacing organoseleninic acid under room temperature.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Organoseleninic acid, similar to carboxylate/sulfonate/phosphinate group, has two coordination oxygen atoms and one negative charge. Therefore, it was thought worthwhile to research the interaction between organotin species and organoseleninic acid. Chandrasekhar et al. reported the first example of an organotin ester of phenylseleninic acid, O2SePh moiety functioning as connector between neighboring Sn centers . To date, there have been no further examples reported in the domain of organoseleninate unit acting as bridging ligand. In this report, we synthesized successfully a new 1D infinite neutral chain (Ph3SnO2SeC2H5O) n  (1). It is noted that the synthesis is facile and selenium oxide is directly introduced into synthesis route replacing organoseleninic acid under room temperature.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">[(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn]Cl, SeO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and ethanol were all purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. [(<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-C<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N]VO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was prepared according to the literature method . SeO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (42<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and [(<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-C<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N]VO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (125<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were dissolved together in 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of dehydrated ethanol and stirred for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Then, the solution of [(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn]Cl (146<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of dehydrated ethanol was added slowly. After the mixture had been stirred for about 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, the filtrate was kept undisturbed for 2 days. Colorless transparent block crystals of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were isolated in about 27% yield (based on [(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn]Cl). Anal. Calcd. (%) for Ph<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SnO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SeC<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O: C, 42.72; H, 3.98; Found (%): C, 42.65; H, 3.92. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 1008 (s, C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O), 886 (s, C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Se), 779 (vs, Se<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O), 638 and 661 (m, Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Sn), 482 (m, Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

[(C6H5)3Sn]Cl, SeO2 and ethanol were all purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. [(n-C4H9)4N]VO3 was prepared according to the literature method . SeO2 (42mg, 0.38mmol) and [(n-C4H9)4N]VO3 (125mg, 0.38mmol) were dissolved together in 5mL of dehydrated ethanol and stirred for 2h. Then, the solution of [(C6H5)3Sn]Cl (146mg, 0.38mmol) in 3mL of dehydrated ethanol was added slowly. After the mixture had been stirred for about 1h, the filtrate was kept undisturbed for 2 days. Colorless transparent block crystals of compound 1 were isolated in about 27% yield (based on [(C6H5)3Sn]Cl). Anal. Calcd. (%) for Ph3SnO2SeC2H5O: C, 42.72; H, 3.98; Found (%): C, 42.65; H, 3.92. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm-1): 1008 (s, CCO), 886 (s, COSe), 779 (vs, SeO), 638 and 661 (m, SnOSn), 482 (m, SnO).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A colorless transparent block single crystal was mounted on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromatized Mo-Kα (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) radiation source at 298(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. The structure was solved by direct methods with SHLXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2 using SHLXTL-97 software package . All non-hydrogen atoms were assigned anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were determined from different Fourier maps and refined with a common isotropic thermal parameter. The crystal belongs to orthorhombic system, space group <ce:italic>Pbca</ce:italic>, with <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>14.6857(12), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>13.7151(11), <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>20.455(2) Å, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4120.0(6) Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0728 and <ce:italic>wR</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.1387. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

A colorless transparent block single crystal was mounted on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromatized Mo-Kα (λ =0.71073Å) radiation source at 298(2)K. The structure was solved by direct methods with SHLXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2 using SHLXTL-97 software package . All non-hydrogen atoms were assigned anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were determined from different Fourier maps and refined with a common isotropic thermal parameter. The crystal belongs to orthorhombic system, space group Pbca, with a =14.6857(12), b =13.7151(11), c =20.455(2) Å, V =4120.0(6) Å3, Z =8, R 1 =0.0728 and wR 2 =0.1387. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in  .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a 1D infinite neutral chain which is composed of [Ph<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations and [O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SeOC<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions. The following reaction might be proceeded:<ce:display>
<ce:formula>
<ce:chem>Ph<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SnCl<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>SeO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Ph<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SnO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SeOCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>HCl</ce:chem>
</ce:formula>
</ce:display>
</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that compound 1 is a 1D infinite neutral chain which is composed of [Ph3Sn]+ cations and [O2SeOC2H5]- anions. The following reaction might be proceeded:  Ph3SnCl+SeO2 +CH3CH2OH→Ph3SnO2SeOCH2CH3 +HCl

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, the Sn atom in compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exists in a slightly distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry with the basal plane being defined by the three phenyl groups and the axial positions being occupied by two O atoms derived from two symmetry related, bridging <ce:sup loc="pre">−</ce:sup>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SeOCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> ligands. Therefore, the Sn atom takes penta-coordination mode. In the trigonal bipyramidal geometry (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>), the sum of the trigonal angles is 359.1° (C(9)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Sn(1)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C(3) 124.3(6)°, C(15)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Sn(1)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C(9) 116.6(6)°, C(15)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Sn(1)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C(3) 118.2(5)°). So, the Sn atom lies in the plane of the three C atoms within experimental error. Furthermore, the axial angle (O(1)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Sn(1)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O(2)#1) is 176.9(4)° which result in the slightly distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. The Se(1) atom coordinates with three O atoms (O(1), O(2), O(3)). The distances of Se<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O are 1.684(11) Å (Se(1)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O(1)), 1.599(10) Å ((Se(1)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O(2)), 1.721(12) Å ((Se(1)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O(3)) respectively. Consequently, the Se center is tri-coordinated with a distorted pyramidal arrangement (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in  , the Sn atom in compound 1 exists in a slightly distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry with the basal plane being defined by the three phenyl groups and the axial positions being occupied by two O atoms derived from two symmetry related, bridging -O2SeOCH2CH3 ligands. Therefore, the Sn atom takes penta-coordination mode. In the trigonal bipyramidal geometry ( ), the sum of the trigonal angles is 359.1° (C(9)Sn(1)C(3) 124.3(6)°, C(15)Sn(1)C(9) 116.6(6)°, C(15)Sn(1)C(3) 118.2(5)°). So, the Sn atom lies in the plane of the three C atoms within experimental error. Furthermore, the axial angle (O(1)Sn(1)O(2)#1) is 176.9(4)° which result in the slightly distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. The Se(1) atom coordinates with three O atoms (O(1), O(2), O(3)). The distances of SeO are 1.684(11) Å (Se(1)O(1)), 1.599(10) Å ((Se(1)O(2)), 1.721(12) Å ((Se(1)O(3)) respectively. Consequently, the Se center is tri-coordinated with a distorted pyramidal arrangement ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>, The <ce:sup loc="pre">−</ce:sup>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SeOCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> moieties are acting as connector symmetrically bridge Ph<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> units through an alternating mode, which leads to a 1D infinite neutral chain. In the structure of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond distances are Sn(1)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O(1) 2.147(9) Å, Sn(1)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O(2)#1 2.262(10) Å. However, the Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond distances are indistinguishable (Sn(1)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O(1) 2.225(5) Å, Sn(1)<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O(2)′ 2.223(4) Å.) in the compound Ph<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SnO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SePh reported by Chandrasekhar group . The difference in Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond distances may be due to the dissimilar bridging ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in  , The -O2SeOCH2CH3 moieties are acting as connector symmetrically bridge Ph3Sn+ units through an alternating mode, which leads to a 1D infinite neutral chain. In the structure of compound 1, the SnO bond distances are Sn(1)O(1) 2.147(9) Å, Sn(1)O(2)#1 2.262(10) Å. However, the SnO bond distances are indistinguishable (Sn(1)O(1) 2.225(5) Å, Sn(1)O(2)' 2.223(4) Å.) in the compound Ph3SnO2SePh reported by Chandrasekhar group . The difference in SnO bond distances may be due to the dissimilar bridging ligands.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In summary, we report here a new 1D infinite neutral chain constructed from organotin and selenium oxide precursor via a simple synthesis route. The successful synthesis of this compound is expected to be effective for the further construction of novel organotin compounds.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, we report here a new 1D infinite neutral chain constructed from organotin and selenium oxide precursor via a simple synthesis route. The successful synthesis of this compound is expected to be effective for the further construction of novel organotin compounds.

cln_elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">[(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn]Cl, SeO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and ethanol were all purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. [(<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-C<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N]VO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was prepared according to the literature method . SeO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (42<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and [(<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-C<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N]VO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (125<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were dissolved together in 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of dehydrated ethanol and stirred for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Then, the solution of [(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn]Cl (146<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of dehydrated ethanol was added slowly. After the mixture had been stirred for about 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, the filtrate was kept undisturbed for 2 days. Colorless transparent block crystals of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were isolated in about 27% yield (based on [(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sn]Cl). Anal. Calcd. (%) for Ph<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SnO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SeC<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O: C, 42.72; H, 3.98; Found (%): C, 42.65; H, 3.92. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 1008 (s, C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O), 886 (s, C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Se), 779 (vs, Se<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O), 638 and 661 (m, Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>Sn), 482 (m, Sn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O).</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental

[(C6H5)3Sn]Cl, SeO2 and ethanol were all purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. [(n-C4H9)4N]VO3 was prepared according to the literature method . SeO2 (42mg, 0.38mmol) and [(n-C4H9)4N]VO3 (125mg, 0.38mmol) were dissolved together in 5mL of dehydrated ethanol and stirred for 2h. Then, the solution of [(C6H5)3Sn]Cl (146mg, 0.38mmol) in 3mL of dehydrated ethanol was added slowly. After the mixture had been stirred for about 1h, the filtrate was kept undisturbed for 2 days. Colorless transparent block crystals of compound 1 were isolated in about 27% yield (based on [(C6H5)3Sn]Cl). Anal. Calcd. (%) for Ph3SnO2SeC2H5O: C, 42.72; H, 3.98; Found (%): C, 42.65; H, 3.92. Selected IR data (KBr pellet, cm-1): 1008 (s, CCO), 886 (s, COSe), 779 (vs, SeO), 638 and 661 (m, SnOSn), 482 (m, SnO).

cln_elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A colorless transparent block single crystal was mounted on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromatized Mo-Kα (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) radiation source at 298(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. The structure was solved by direct methods with SHLXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2 using SHLXTL-97 software package . All non-hydrogen atoms were assigned anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were determined from different Fourier maps and refined with a common isotropic thermal parameter. The crystal belongs to orthorhombic system, space group <ce:italic>Pbca</ce:italic>, with <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>14.6857(12), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>13.7151(11), <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>20.455(2) Å, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4120.0(6) Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.0728 and <ce:italic>wR</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.1387. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

A colorless transparent block single crystal was mounted on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromatized Mo-Kα (λ =0.71073Å) radiation source at 298(2)K. The structure was solved by direct methods with SHLXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F2 using SHLXTL-97 software package . All non-hydrogen atoms were assigned anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were determined from different Fourier maps and refined with a common isotropic thermal parameter. The crystal belongs to orthorhombic system, space group Pbca, with a =14.6857(12), b =13.7151(11), c =20.455(2) Å, V =4120.0(6) Å3, Z =8, R 1 =0.0728 and wR 2 =0.1387. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in  .

metadata.title: Synthesis and structure of a new 1D infinite neutral chain based on organotin and selenious acid monoethyl ester
metadata.journal: Chang Wen Hu. Published by Elsevier B.V.
